Fields.DialogueText: La la la... la!
Is that you singing, Riedel?
AAH! Ach du meine Güte!
... Don't just sneak up on a person like that, Kapitän.
Sorry, I didn't mean to scare you. What are you doing out here, anyway?
I was just wandering. And thinking. I'll admit, I'm the type whose head is often in the clouds.

Fields.MenuText: What were you thinking about?
I'm a bit of a daydreamer myself.
I need you here in reality, Riedel. I don't want the Morganas catching you off guard.

Fields.DialogueText: Oh, nothing of any merit, I promise. About the last book I read, I think.
It's a good way to relax, don't you think? A short term form of escapism.
Oh, of course, Kapitän. I assure you, I am battle-ready at all times.
Is this where you do most of your wandering and thinking?
Ja. It is quiet here most hours of the day, so it is an ideal place. If you're ever in need of a place to think, you're welcome to use it as well.
I'll keep that in mind. Thanks, Riedel.
Of course, Kapitän!
*ALARM*
Looks as if you're going to have to cut your introspection time short.
That's quite all right. I never mind going toe to toe with a few Nixen.
@BATTLE
What's that sticking out of your pocket, Riedel?
What? This? Oh, it's nothing.
It looks like a book. Well, the corner of one, anyway.
And so it is.
Any book in particular?
Just a notebook.
Ah. What sort of notes do you take in said notebook?
Riedel?
*ALARM*
Well, would you look at that? Looks as if we have a few Nixen headed our direction.
You'd really rather not share about that notebook of yours, would you?
It's nothing against you, Kapitän. But... ja.
All right, all right. I'll leave it alone. Ready to fight?
Natürlich, Kapitän.
@BATTLE
Tell me a little about where you're from, Riedel.
Certainly, Kapitän. I hail from Germany, of course. Bremen, to be more exact. But I've also spent some time in the western Mediterranean.
And what are your thoughts on the German Navy?
I'm loyal to my homeland, of course. But I'll admit, I have little difficulty empathizing with the viewpoints of other nations...
That's for the best. We're all having to work together, in this war against the Morganas.
I'm confident that, with our combined forces, those sea witches won't stand a chance against us.
That's good to hear.
Where are you from, Kapitän?

Fields.MenuText: Nowhere of any importance, really.
I don't know that it's any of your business, Riedel.

Fields.DialogueText: I think nowhere sounds as if it could be a very nice place to visit.
Oh! But you asked me... never mind..
Well, it's best that we keep both our homes close to our hearts. That will give us the motivation we need in this war.
*ALARM*
Looks as if it's time to put that motivation to good use.
@BATTLE

Fields.MenuText: I haven't told you about home? Hang on! Let me get my scrapbook!

Fields.DialogueText: ... Actually, belay that. When I'm off-duty.
Of course.
We need to move, Kapitän. That horde of Nixen is on our tail, and we can't face them all at once.
Find the engineers, have them pick up speed. Hopefully, the slower Morganas will turn back before the faster Morganas catch up with us.
Does this mean we're going to have to fight them?

Fields.MenuText: Yes.
Not necessarily.
Some of them, more than likely.

Fields.DialogueText: Well, I guess it can't be helped.
I don't know... the faster Nixen are closing in.
We're up to the task, aren't we?
Don't worry, Riedel. We can take them.
I'm happy to hear you're confident. A group that size, well... it just scares me a little, that's all.
A little fear now and then keeps us from getting complacent. There's nothing wrong with that, Riedel.
I appreciate the words of encouragement, Kapitän.
Hmm... well, the slower Morganas have turned back. But the faster ones are nearly upon us.
Stations?
Yes, to stations.
@BATTLE
All hands to battle stations! Enemy inbound!
@BATTLE
Kapitän, do you enjoy... fairy tales?

Fields.MenuText: Actually, yes. I find them fascinating.
Not particularly. They're a little fanciful for my tastes.
I don't have strong feelings on the subject either way.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm so pleased to hear you're a fan as well! I read them all the time.
Oh, well, that's a shame. I love them, and was hoping you might be a kindred spirit.
Really? Well... maybe you should give the subject a little more thought.
Which story is your favorite?
I like them all, but if I had to pick one, I'd probably choose "Die Bremer Stadtmusikanten."
You don't say?
I do! It's about a donkey, a dog, a cat and a rooster who all decide to go to Bremen to become musicians.
But on their way, they see some robbers. Together, they scare the robbers away and take up residence in the house.
So, they never make it to Bremen?
Um, no, they don't. At least, not in the original version.
That's a strange tale, Riedel.
Now, be nice. It is my favorite story, remember.
Sorry, sorry. I didn't mean to offend.
Oh, it takes more than that to offend me. And, besides, if you do read it one day, I'm sure you'll see that it is quite satisfying.
I'm sure I will, Riedel.
I've been giving your favorite fairy tale some thought, Riedel. What's the meaning behind it?
Have you read it yet?

Fields.MenuText: Yes!
No...
I want to, but I haven't had time yet.

Fields.DialogueText: Really? Well, I hope you liked it, Kapitän.
Well, I guess I'll tell you anyway.
Well, I suppose I'll take pity on you.
Why is it called "Die Bremer Stadtmusikanten" if the animals never make it to Bremen or become musicians in the first place?
Also, to scare the robbers away, they cry out in their loudest voices. Oh, and break a window. If you like, you could say that that's their music.
Early atonal composition. Surprisingly modern.
The animals were all past their prime and in search of a place they could be free. As it turns out, they didn't have to travel all the way to Bremen to find a new home.
Hmm... I can understand the appeal of finding a home.
Grimm's Fairy Tales are much deeper than one might expect. They're all worth a read.
*ALARM*
Certainly, Riedel. But I think we'd better go out and defeat these Morganas before we get lost in old stories.
Agreed.
@BATTLE
I think you could say that the story's called that because it's how they thought of themselves. It's about reinvention when times get bad as much as anything else.
Hm.
I'm sorry?
No, *I'm* sorry. Carry on.
Those Morganas... look at them stalking that horizon. I'd bet they're planning on stealing supplies from nearby trade ships.
We need to put an end to that.
Regardless of whether the ships are Allied or Axis?
We're all on the same side right now, Kapitän. Where are the closest trade ships?

Fields.MenuText: We don't have that information.
I'm sure we'll find out soon.
They're not far from us.

Fields.DialogueText: We'd better find out quickly, then.
Good. Our scouts are the best of the best, I hear.
Then we should strike the Nixen soon. We can't let them gain a foothold in this war.
A little strategy would do us good before we charge in.
Natürlich, Kapitän. I know you have quite the mind for tactics.
You really think that?
I've been impressed by our battles thus far.
Well then, I certainly can't let you down this time, can I?
@BATTLE
Kapitän, come look over here.
OOF!
Did I just hear a crash?
No, it's nothing. I'm fine. Really.
You just tripped and fell. I can see scrapes on your knees.
Oh, these? Yeah... I'm fine, though.

Fields.MenuText: You ought to be more careful.
I knew someone once who was just as clumsy as you.
Those scratches don't look so bad.

Fields.DialogueText: I will be, Kapitän. But I'm fine, really.
I don't know if I want to hear what happened to them...
They aren't. Trust me, I've had far worse.
Still, I want you to be careful. We can't have accidents in war.
It's a big ocean, and there's nothing to trip over at sea.
What did you want to show me, anyhow? You called me over.
Look at the sky. Those clouds are pretty, aren't they?
All I see are those large Morgana ships.
@BATTLE
You don't seem to be phased by the Morganas, Riedel.
I'm not afraid of them. But fighting isn't an activity I'm particularly enamored with, either.

Fields.MenuText: But you're good at it.
None of us like it.
You don't have to fight.

Fields.DialogueText: I am good at it, Kapitän. But that doesn't mean I enjoy it.
War is just a necessary evil, I suppose.
Kapitän, saying that is like saying I don't need to float, and it's just not true.
War is always difficult, Riedel.
Why do we all have to suffer so much?
The Morganas don't suffer. They don't eat, they don't sleep.
All they do is kill. And we need to stop that.
You don't know that they don't suffer. I... I'd be willing to wage that they do.
Still, it's them or us.
Ja. You're right. I know I need to protect my homeland.
So you see why we need to buckle down and fight?
*ALARM*
Ja. Let's do it.
@BATTLE
You're a gentle soul, Riedel.
Oh! Danke, Kapitän. ... No one's ever said that to me before.
Well, it's true. I know it makes fighting the Morganas difficult...
Don't worry, Kapitän. I'm going to be fine. My armaments are ready, and I'll follow all orders.

Fields.MenuText: That's good to hear.
We're going to need a lot of preparation.
I'm still nervous.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm going to fight hard no matter how I feel, Kapitän.
I'm already stocking up on ammunition and supplies.
Don't worry, Kapitän. We are going to be fine.
Life is sometimes difficult, Riedel. It's ugly and bad things happen.
Sometimes I think about my fairy tales... everything ends happily in those.
Although, now that I think about it, maybe it doesn't end happily for everyone.
Those tales of yours have a pretty high death count, don't they?
Don't make me think about that.
*ALARM*
Let's make sure we're not part of our story's death count.
@BATTLE
Kapitän, have you seen my notebook anywhere? It's small and red. Kind of like my cape.
No, I haven't seen it anywhere. Is it important?
It didn't contain anything too serious. Just fairy tales of my own making.
You've written your own fairy tales?
I have! Sometimes, the characters are based on the crew.

Fields.MenuText: What kind of animal am I?
Do the stories have happy endings?
Are they any good?

Fields.DialogueText: You're usually a human, Kapitän, and the rest of us are animals.
Some do, but a few of them don't. I like to dabble and be diverse.
What does good mean, anyway? We just make up stories, it's up for you to decide what's good.
If I come across your notebook, I will let you know. Now, you didn't put anything else in there right? Nothing that should be kept secret?
Well... umm... no.
Are you sure?
Ja, Kapitän.
If you say so...
(whispers) Ich muss das Notizbuch finden. Schnell.
Pardon?
If you'll excuse me, Kapitän, I'm going to check the mess hall.
*ALARM*
Maybe wait until after this battle.
@BATTLE
Alle Mann auf Gefechtsstation! Feind im Anmarsch!
@BATTLE
Wo könnte es sein? Ugh. I hate losing things.
Still can't find it?
Waah!
*THUD*
Theodor Riedel, are you all right? That looked like a nasty fall.
I'm fine, I'm fine. You keep surprising me like that.
That's an awfully bad bump on your head. You ought to get it checked out.
I need to find that notebook first...

Fields.MenuText: What's so important about it, anyway?
It'll show up eventually.
Just get a new notebook.

Fields.DialogueText: It has all of my notes and stories and... stuff.
I don't think I'll be able to focus unless I get that book back.
A new notebook doesn't have all of my stories and writings, Kapitän.
Have you tried looking in the engine room?
Hmm... no, I haven't. I'll check.
What an odd girl.
Alle Mann auf Gefechtsstation! Feind im Anmarsch!
@BATTLE
There you go. All bandaged up.
Kapitän, please, there's no reason for so much fuss. I'm not a child.
I don't know too many adults who're so devoted to fairy tales.
Are you insinuating that I'm immature because of what I read?

Fields.MenuText: Yes.
No. Sorry, that came out wrong.
That's not what I meant.

Fields.DialogueText: That's just not nice. Fairy tales have lessons for people of all ages.
Good. Fairy tales have a lot of literary merit, you know.
Well, it certainly sounded like you meant that...
Tell me about them. What's their appeal for you?
I think I like them because they all are about adventures and magic. They remind the reader that anything is possible.
Aren't we on some kind of adventure right now?
In the stories, everything always wraps up. But out here, in the real world...
I won't argue with that.
Kapitän, Nixen have been sighted.
They don't stand a chance against us.
Don't get overconfident. None of us know how this story is going to end.
You don't believe we're going to win this war?

Fields.MenuText: Of course I do. What a silly question.
I just want to prevent the loss of my crew.
Can the war be over already?

Fields.DialogueText: All we need to do is stay strong, Kapitän.
War is filled with tragedy...
No, we have so much left to do, sadly.
Do we have supplies for this battle?
The crew is on standby. We're awaiting your next orders.
You know what? Let's attack these Morganas head on.
You're not worried about the danger ahead?
Sometimes, a full frontal assault is just the ticket.
Jawohl!
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Are there other fairy tales you like? Besides the one with the animals who don't make it to Bremen?
Well, I have quite a few other favorites.
I suppose you've read them all.
Natürlich. I have an entire collection of the Grimms' Fairy Tales.
Die Bremer Stadtmusikanten.
Ja! It's taught me much about myself and my potential, Kapitän. Sometimes, you don't know what you're capable of until you choose to speak.
Hmm, that's a good lesson to be learned.
What kind of stories do you like, Kapitän?

Fields.MenuText: Romance.
Adventure.
Ones written by the Black Chicken.

Fields.DialogueText: I love romantic stories. Especially the ones with the happy endings.
Action and adventure are great, but sometimes they remind me too much of the real world.
The Black Chicken? You mean the Russian story?
That being said, I don't have much time for reading now. We've got too much to think about in the near future.
You deserve some relaxation time now and then, Kapitän.
*ALARM*
Not with Morganas lurking at every turn.
@BATTLE
No, no. More recent. "Black Chicken" is certainly a pen name, but I found the work very interesting.
An "entire collection?" Isn't it just-
Multiple editions! I even have a first edition - though that one doesn't have my favourite story.
Kapitän, I thought we received intel that Nixen would be in this area. Where are they?
The information might have been wrong. I worry what surprises are in store for us now.
Whatever happens, I'll make sure I'm prepared.
That's a bold attitude, Riedel.
Thank you, Kapitän. Even in unfortunate times of war, we must stay vigilant.

Fields.MenuText: Vigilance is the key to success.
There's no question the Morganas will take advantage of us if we give them the opportunity.
I'm of the mind that there's such a thing as being too vigilant. You can miss the forest for the trees if you remain too focused.

Fields.DialogueText: I hope that one day we will live in a world where we don't need to look over our shoulders at all times.
That does seem to be their specialty, doesn't it?
I suppose one could miss the big picture amidst the details.
Hmm... what's that on the horizon, over there?
I think you know what that is, Kapitän.
Looks as if our intel was right, after all.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Ahh, Riedel. Enjoying the sky, I see. How long have you been up, today?
Please don't disturb me, Kapitän. I'm writing a story.
You found your book?
I had to get a new one. This one feels strange. The paper is thin and cheap. And the cover is rough on my hands.

Fields.MenuText: It looks pretty cheap to me.
You could just toss it.
Who cares? It's a new book.

Fields.DialogueText: But it gets the job done. I suppose I shouldn't complain.
I've already started something, Kapitän.
Well, this is true. It's better than nothing, that's for sure.
Can I see what you've written?
Sorry, Kapitän. I don't let anyone read my work. But...  I can tell you what it's about. If you want.
*BOOM*
I'd love to hear all about it, but not right now. It sounds as if Morganas are on the hunt.
On my way to my Gefechtsstation, Kapitän!
@BATTLE
Alle Mann auf Gefechtsstation! Feind im Anmarsch!
@BATTLE
So, it looks as if the Morganas are gone. For now, at least.
I understand the threat the Nixen pose... and yet, I can't help but feel some small sense of relief when they escape. I hate the thought of killing anything.
Sometimes, you don't have a choice.
... I know.
So, do you want to tell me about that story?
I was honestly hoping you'd forget...
Forget? Of course not. I'm honestly curious, Riedel.
Well then, let me find the story.... Here it is.
It's about a young fox who meets a little mouse. Together, they sail across an ocean to find treasure.
And that's it so far. So, what do you think?

Fields.MenuText: I like both foxes and mice, so I'm interested.
I want to hear where it goes.
Eh... maybe it's just not my sort of story.

Fields.DialogueText: It's not my best work, but it has been fun to write.
I'm not done yet. Maybe I'll share more once it's finished.
That's just an outline, Kapitän. I'm sure it will improve with more content.
It's at least nice that you spend some of your free time doing something creative, Riedel.
Danke. Now if you'll excuse me, I need some privacy.
Kapitän, you seem to be troubled. Is something the matter?

Fields.MenuText: Our last battle depleted many of our resources.
I just heard bad news from Command.
I think I'm getting ill.

Fields.DialogueText: Well, we'll just have to restock next time we make port, then.
I heard too. The Nixen are ruthless, aren't they? But that just gives us more reason to fight.
Why don't you lie down? I'll send for some soup and read you a story.
You don't seem too bothered, Riedel.
I consider it my responsibility to keep you and the crew in good spirits. The happier we are, the easier it is to persevere.
I understand the importance of morale, but sometimes I can't help but worry about the ship.
It's going to be fine, Kapitän. I promise.
*ALARM*
Here's your chance to prove it.
@BATTLE
Do you have a favorite movie, Riedel?
I do! Schneewittchen. The animated version.
... I've heard that, yes.
There was something magical about that film. It had singing, it had action, it had magic too. What more could you want?
You really are a fan, aren't you?
Ja - natürlich! I could watch that film over and over, given the opportunity.

Fields.MenuText: Oh, yeah. Great film!
No. But maybe we'll have a showing on board, someday.
Yeah, but... well, let's just say I can't imagine watching it multiple times.

Fields.DialogueText: *sigh*
Really? Oh, that would be wonderful!
Your tastes may be very different from mine, Kapitän.
It's been a long time since I saw a movie.
Really? Well then, we need a screening as soon as possible.
*ALARM*
Think the Morganas would like to join in?
They're not on any guest list of mine.
@BATTLE
Ah. Walt Disney rears his head and-
Nein! Betty Boop! So experimental!
It wasn't easy to get a hold of it. They say it's too degenerate for Germany.
And what about the Disney one? Not your thing?
Oh, I'm sure it *is* my thing. I just haven't been able to find a copy yet. Have you?
I'll ask around. Maybe we can secure a copy for you.
Theodor, you may want to go into the mess hall.
Why? Are they serving German food again? You know that hot dogs don't count as bratwurst, right?
No, I think your notebook's been found. I overheard a few sailors reading from it and told them you'd be by to collect it.
Oh, my... they read it?
I'm afraid so. They seemed to enjoy it, for what it's worth.
Be honest. How much did you hear?

Fields.MenuText: None at all.
Just a little bit.
I heard a lot.

Fields.DialogueText: What a relief. There are stories I do not want you to hear.
I just hope you didn't hear anything too embarrassing, Kapitän.
Ugh, I'm so embarrassed. You shouldn't have heard anything.
Try not to think about it. And if anybody gives you any trouble over what you've written, you know you can-
Oh, I won't have any trouble. Those Matrosen haven't seen my dark side yet.
Dark side?
Wait, Riedel! Don't hurt anyone...
It's not worth that much!
Riedel, slow down.
No way. They have my notebook. I need it back, or I'll be the laughing stock of the whole ship.
I don't blame you for being upset. But you look like you're ready to kill anyone who stands in your way.
... I guess I am pretty stressed out.
Just relax, Riedel. You'll get it back. Don't worry.
I just don't want anyone to make fun of me...

Fields.MenuText: It's okay. I'm sensitive too.
No one will make fun of you.
Getting angry isn't the right solution.

Fields.DialogueText: I just hate the idea of people being mean to each other. We should all get along.
You haven't heard everything I've written. Some things shouldn't be read aloud.
I'm not angry.
*ALARM*
Just relax. You'll prove yourself in the battles ahead of us.
Right, Kapitän. Even if my stories are silly, do you think the crew will still take me seriously?
As long as you perform well in battle, I can't imagine they'll have a choice in the matter.
@BATTLE
... Okay, maybe I am a little upset. I should calm down.
Alle Mann auf Gefechtsstation! Feind im Anmarsch!
@BATTLE
How does it feel to have the notebook back in your hand?
It's kind of gross. There are oil stains and thumbprints all over it. Some people don't know how to take care of others' things.
I'll discipline the crew. They should know better than to treat things - especially what's not theirs - so poorly.
Nein. It's my fault for losing it in the first place. I'll be more careful from now on.
Good to know.
I caught them reading a very... intense story when I walked in and grabbed my book back.
What happened next?
They looked at me like I was crazy to take the book back. So I gave them the "bösen Blick," my sternest glare. They were pretty silent after that.

Fields.MenuText: I'm glad you got your notebook back. It's about time.
Now, you should get back to writing more stories.
What was so "intense" about that story?

Fields.DialogueText: I thought I'd never get it back, Kapitän. You have no idea.
I already have one in my head right now.
Oh nothing. Just two soldiers, getting a little... frivol.
Just don't lose it again. I don't want to go through all this trouble again.
Alle Mann auf Gefechtsstation! Feind im Anmarsch!
@BATTLE
Ich bin geschafft! No more fighting, please.
You're tired already?
Hey, I worked hard out there.
Well, that is true. But you can't just give up.
Who said I was going to give up? I just need a little rest.

Fields.MenuText: A good soldier's work is never done.
The more Morganas we fight, the sooner this war ends.
I feel exhausted too.

Fields.DialogueText: You're right. I need to fight harder, even if I don't feel like I like it.
That's right. A nice benefit from all of the constant fighting.
You've worked so hard, Kapitän. I hope you are able to relax soon.
Every day, we're a little closer to the end of this war.
Hey, Kapitän. Look at the sky.
It's quite the sight.
With a beautiful image like that, we must have a happy ending.
I can't say I disagree.
Alle Mann auf Gefechtsstation! Feind im Anmarsch!
@BATTLE
So in the original story, Die Bremer Stadtmusikanten tells us that we may not always be equipped to do our job, but that doesn't mean we're worth nothing.
I didn't want to fight in a war.
None of us do, you know.
But it feels like I found my music here.
You're not planning on picking up and leaving any time soon?
As if I could. Besides, I think you need me more than I need you.
Do you see me arguing?
Not in the least.
The Morganas are out of the picture for a little while. So, we'll be able to rest up for a bit.
A little relaxation sounds perfect to me.
How about we see whether we can't screen a particular movie aboard the ship? The one with the dwarves.
Oh, boy. Would you really be able to do that for me?

Fields.MenuText: Of course, Theodor. Maybe it'll inspire your next story.
Of course, Theodor. I'm pretty excited to see it, myself.
